title-group.article-title: Arundinosides I-IX and graminifolosides A-B: 2R-benzylmalate and 2R-isobutylmalates derivatives from Arundina graminifolia (D.Don) Hochr. with antioxidant, cytocompatibility and cytoprotective properties

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Arundinosides I-IX and graminifolosides A-B: 2R-benzylmalate and 2R-isobutylmalates derivatives from Arundina graminifolia (D.Don) Hochr. with antioxidant, cytocompatibility and cytoprotective properties

sec.p: ARTICLE INFO

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Glucosyloxybenzyl 2 R -benzylmalate derivatives
Glucosyloxybenzyl 2 R -isobutylmalate derivatives
Arundinosides I-IX
Graminifolosides A-B
ABSTRACT

Phytochemical investigation of the underground parts of
Arundina graminifolia D.Don Hochr
was conducted leading to the isolation of nine new glucosyloxybenzyl 2 R -benzylmalate and two new glucosyloxybenzyl 2 R - isobutylmalate derivatives. The compounds were purified using chromatographic techniques and their structures were deduced based on spectroscopic techniques including nuclear magnetic resonance and high-resolution mass spectrometry as well as comparing with previous literature. The antioxidant activities of the isolated compounds were also evaluated. The compounds showed potent antioxidant activities in the ABTS radical scavenging, DPPH radical scavenging and FRAP activities. Furthermore, the isolated compounds were observed to exert minimal cytotoxic effects against RAW 264.7 cell, suggesting biocompatibility as well as cytoprotective effects against hydrogen peroxide induced cell toxicity.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p:

,b) with several pharmacological activities including antibacterial, antiviral, cytotoxic and anti-liver fibrotic effects. As a furtherance to the studies on the bioactive constituents from
A. graminifolia D.Don Hochr
, nine new glucosyloxybenzyl 2R-benzylmalate, arundinosides I-IX (1–9) and two new glucosyloxybenzyl 2 R -isobutylmalates, graminifolosides A-B (10–11) were isolated and identified from the underground part of the plant.

sec.title: 2. Results and discussion
sec.p:
Arundinoside I (1) was obtained as a white amorphous powder with the molecular formula of C 38 H 46 O 20 , which was determined from the HRESIMS at m/z 840.2915 [M + NH 4 ] + . The 13 C NMR data showed resonances corresponding to 34 carbons; including four methyls, five methylenes, nine sp 2 methines, ten sp 3 methines and six carbonyl carbons. Comparison of the NMR spectroscopic data ( Table 1 ) of 1 with those of arundinoside T, a previously isolated compound from
A . graminifolia D. Don Hochr
indicated that compound 1 shared similar structural features with it (benzylmalic acid and glucosyloxybenzyl moieties) (
). Compound 1 differs from arundioside T based on the acetyl substituent attached to C-6 ′′′ ’. The benzylmalic-glucosyloxybenzyl skeleton is composed of a benzylmalic unit [ δH / δC 3.11, 2.96 (d, J = 17.8 Hz, H-3)/44.3; 3.01, 2.94 (d, J = 13.5 Hz, H-5)/47.3; 7.02 (m, H-7/11)/132.0; 7.15 (m, H-8/10)/129.1; δC 172.7 (C-1), 82.5 (C-2), 174.0 (C-4) and 136.5 (C-6)] and a glucosyloxybenzyl unit [ δH / δC 7.28 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, H-2’/6 ′ )/131.7; 7.07 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, H-3’/5 ′ )/117.9; 5.11, 4.95 (d, J = 12.0 Hz, H-7 ′ )/67.9; 4.93 (d, J = 7.4 Hz, 4 ′ - O -glc-1 ′′′ ’)/102.3; 3.47 (m, 4 ′ - O -glc-2 ′′′ ’)/75.0; 3.47 (dd, J = 9.3, 9.3 Hz, 4 ′ - O -glc-3 ′′′ ’)/77.9; 3.39 (dd, J = 9.3, 9.3 Hz, 4 ′ - O -glc-4 ′′′ ’)/71.6; 3.66 (ddd, J = 9.3, 6.1, 2.2 Hz, 4 ′ - O -glc-5 ′′′ ’)/75.4; 4.24 (dd, J = 11.9, 6.1 Hz, 4 ′ - O -glc-6a’’’’) and 4.41 (dd, J = 11.9, 2.2 Hz, 4 ′ - O -glc-6b’’’’)/64.8; 2.07 (s, 6 ′′′ ’-Ac-2)/20.9; δC 131.0 (C-1 ′ ), 159.2 (C-4 ′ ) and 172.9 (C-6 ′′′ ’-Ac-1)]. The resonance of an additional acetyl group at C-6 ′′′ [ δH / δC 2.05 (s, 6 ′′′ -Ac-2/20.9; δC 172.8 (C-6 ′′′ -Ac-1)] on the glucose unit connected to C-2 of the benzylmalic unit which replaces the hydroxyl group in arundioside T was confirmed by HMBC correlations of H-6 ′′′ with C-6 ′′′ -Ac-1 and H-6 ′′′ -Ac-2 with C-6 ′′′ -Ac-1. The absolute configuration of 1 was determined by alkaline hydrolysis that yielded a 2R-benzymalic acid, which was identified by

Arundinoside II (2) was also obtained as a white amorphous solid with a molecular formula of C 41 H 46 O 18 according to its HR-ESI-MS data [M-H] - ion at m/z 825.2546. Analysis of the NMR data ( Table 1 ) suggested that compound 2 was similar to compound 1, suggesting that both compounds have structural similarities (benzylmalic and glucosyloxybenzyl moieties), except for the absence of the acetyl groups at C- 3 ′′′ , C-6?and C-6 ′′′ ’. In addition, the presence of a trans -cinnamoyl moiety at δH / δC 7.64 (dd, J = 7.7, 2.1 Hz, H-3 ′′′ ’-Cin-2/6)/129.4; 7.42 (m, H- 3 ′′′ ’-Cin-3/5)/130.2; 7.42 (m, H-3 ′′′ ’-Cin-4)/131.6; 7.77 (d, J = 16.0 Hz, H-3 ′′′ ’-Cin-7)/146.5; 6.64 (d, J = 16.0 Hz, H-3 ′′′ ’-Cin-8)/119.3; δC 136.0 (C– H-3 ′′′ ’-Cin-1) and 168.5 (C– H-3 ′′′ ’-Cin-9) in 2 replaced the hydroxyl group at C-3 ′′′ ’ in 1. The position of the trans -cinnamoyl moiety was confirmed by HMBC correlations of H-3 ′′′ ’ and H-3 ′′′ ’-Cin-7 with C-3 ′′′ ’- Cin-9, H-3 ′′′ ’-Cin-8 with C– H-3 ′′′ ’-Cin-1 and H-3 ′′′ ’-Cin-7 with C-3 ′′′ ’- Cin-2/6. The absolute configuration of 2 was determined using the same method as that of 1. Thus, arundinoside II was elucidated as 1-(ss- Dglucopyranosyloxybenzyl-3-trans-cinnamoyl)-2-(ss- D-glucopyranosyl-2- acetyl)-2R-benzylmalic acid.
Table 1 ( continued )

Arundinoside IV (4) was purified as a white amorphous powder with a molecular formula of C 56 H 64 O 25 as established by the HR-ESI-MS [M- H] - ion peak at m/z 1135.3583 (calcd. for C 56 H 63 O 25 for 1135.3663). Analysis of the 1 H and 13 C NMR spectral data ( Table 2 ) of 4 suggested that the planar structure compound 4 was similar to arundinoside Z (
); one benzylmalic acid, two hydroxybenzoyl, three sugars, one acetyl group on C-2 ′′′ , one cinnamoyl group on c-3 ′′′ ’, except for the presence of an acetyl group at C-6 ′′′ ’ in 4 [ δH / δC 1.69 (s, H-2 ′′′ -Ac-2)/21.4; δC 172.7 (C-2 ′′′ -Ac-1). This was confirmed by the HMBC correlations between H-6 ′′′ ’ and C-2 ′′′ -Ac-1 and H-2 ′′′ -Ac-2 to C-2 ′′′ -Ac-1. The absolute configuration of 4 was determined using the same method as that of 1. Thus, 4 was deduced as 1-(ss- D-glucopyranosyloxybenzyl-3- trans -cinnamoyl-6-acetyl)-2-(ss- D-glucopyranosyl-2- acetyl)-4-(ss- D-glucopyranosyloxybenzyl)-2 R -benzylmalic acid (see Fig. 1 ).
Table 2 ( continued )

Arundinoside V (5) was isolated as a white amorphous powder. The [M –H] - ion peak appeared at m/z 1135.358 (calcd. for C 56 H 63 O 25 for 1135.3663) in the HRESIMS spectrum indicated the same molecular formula of C 56 H 64 O 25 as compound 4. Apart from the absence of the acetyl group at C-6 ′′′ ’, the 1 H and 13 C NMR spectroscopic data ( Table 2 ) of 5 was quite similar with those of 4. The acetyl group was however positioned at C-6 ′′′ . The HMBC correlations of H-6 ′′′ with C-6 ′′′ -Ac-1 and H-6 ′′′ -Ac-2 with C-6 ′′′ -Ac-1 proved the position of acetyl group at C-6 ′′′ ’ (see Fig. 2 ). The absolute configuration of the benzylmalic acid (2R) was determined by using the same method employed for the previous compounds described above. Compound 5 was thus elucidated as 1-(ss- Dglucopyranosyloxybenzyl-3- trans -cinnamoyl)-2-(ss- D-glucopyranosyl-2, 6-diacetyl)-4-(ss- D-glucopyranosyloxybenzyl)-2 R -benzylmalic acid.

Arundinoside VI (6) was isolated as a white amorphous solid with the same molecular formula (C 56 H 64 O 25 ) as compounds 4 and 5. The NMR spectroscopic data ( Table 2 ) of 6 showed strong resemblance to those of 5, suggesting that 6 is also a 2 R -benzylmalate derivative. The only difference between these two compounds was the absence of the acetyl group attached to C-6 ′′′ in 6 which was now positioned at C-3 ′′′ . This was confirmed by HMBC correlations of H-4 ′′′ and H-3 ′′′ -Ac-2 with C-3 ′′′ -Ac- 1. The 2 R configuration was assigned to 6 based on the negative optical rotation as previously described for other 2R-benzylmalate derivative. Arundinoside VI was proposed structurally as shown and elucidated as 1-(ss- D-glucopyranosyloxybenzyl-3- trans -cinnamoyl)-2-(ss- D-glucopyranosyl-2,3-diacetyl)-4-(ss- D-glucopyranosyloxybenzyl)-2 R -benzylmalic acid (see Fig. 3 ).

Arundinoside VII (7) had a molecular formula of C 56 H 63 O 25 deduced from its HR-ESI-MS data at m/z 1135.3542 [M-H] - (calcd. for C 56 H 63 O 25 for 1135.3663). The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectral ( Table 3 ) of 7 revealed an overall structural resemblance to 4, except for the difference in the position of the trans -cinnamoyl moiety at C-4 ′′′ ’ in 7 due to the HMBC correlations of H-4 ′′′ ’ with C-4 ′′′ ’- Cin -9. Accordingly, the structure of 7 was assigned as shown and elucidated as 1-( ss -D-glucopyranosyloxybenzyl-4- trans -cinnamoyl-6-acetyl)-2-( ss -D-glucopyranosyl-2-acetyl)-4- ( ss -D-glucopyranosyloxybenzyl)-2 R -benzylmalic acid (see Fig. 3 ).

Arundinoside VIII (8) showed similar 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra data ( Table 3 ) with those of 7, except for the presence of an additional acetyl group. The HRESIMS data of 8 ( m/z 1177.3715 [M-H] - ; calcd. for C 58 H 65 O 26 for 1177.3710) was consistent with the molecular formula of C 58 H 66 O 26 and the difference in the m/z values of 43 amu compared to 7. The additional acetyl group signal [ δH / δC 1.97 (s, H-6 ′′′ -Ac-2)/20.9; δC 172.9 (C-6 ′′′ -Ac-1)] in the 1 H and 13 C NMR resonances as well as HMBC cross peaks of H-6 ′′′ with C-6 ′′′ -Ac-2 confirmed that an acetyl group is substituted at C-6 ′′′ (see Fig. 3 ).. Compound 8 was therefore elucidated as 1-(ss- D-glucopyranosyloxybenzyl-3- trans -cinnamoyl-6-acetyl)-2-(ss- Dglucopyranosyl-2,6-diacetyl)-4-(ss- D-glucopyranosyloxybenzyl)-2 R -benzylmalic acid.

Arundinoside IX (9) was assigned a molecular formula of C 63 H 68 O 25 according to the HR-ESI-MS peak at m/z 1242.4394 [M + NH 4 ] + (calcd.for C 63 H 72 NO 25 for 1242.4387). The NMR data of 9 showed characteristic features of one benzylmalic acid, two glucosyloxybenzyl, three ss- Dglucose, one acetyl and two trans -cinnamoyl acid moieties. Analysis of the NMR data of 9 ( Table 3 ) showed an overall structural resemblance to arundinoside A (
),except for the presence of a hydroxyl which replaced the acetyl group at C-2?in arundinoside A. On the basis of these findings, the structure of compound 9 was identified as 1-( ss - D- glucopyranosyloxybenzyl-3,4-di- trans -cinnamoyl-6-acetyl)-2-( ss -D-glucopyranosyl)-4-( ss -D-glucopyranosyl-oxybenzyl)-2 R -benzylmalate (see Fig. 4 )..

Based on the HR-ESI-MS data m/z 1208. 1208.4513 [M + NH 4 ] + , the molecular formula of graminifoloside B (11) was deduced as C 60 H 70 O 25 . The spectroscopic data of compound 11 were very similar to those of 10. A detailed analysis of the 1 H and 13 C NMR data revealed the presence of two glucosyloxybenzyl, three sugars and one isobutylmalic acid moieties analogous to those in compound 10. The most noticeable difference in these data were the presence of additional signals assigned to a trans - cinnamoyl moiety at C-3 ′′′ ’ in 11 ( Table 4 ). These difference were confirmed by 1 H NMR signals at δH 7.54 (m, 3 ′ ′ ′ ′ -cin-2/6), 7.38 (m, 3 ′ ′ ′ ′ - cin-3/5), 7.68 (d, J = 15.9 Hz, 3 ′ ′ ′ ′ -cin-4) and 6.52 (d, J = 15.9 Hz, 3 ′ ′ ′ ′ - cin-8) and in the 13 C NMR δC 135.6 (3 ′ ′ ′ ′ -cin-1), 129.5 (3 ′ ′ ′ ′ -cin-2/6), 130.2 (3 ′ ′ ′ ′ -cin-3/5), 131.8 (3 ′ ′ ′ ′ -cin-4), 147.3 (3 ′ ′ ′ ′ -cin-7), 118.3 (3 ′ ′ ′ ′ - cin-8) and 168.0 (3 ′ ′ ′ ′ -cin-9). These analogies were confirmed by HMBC correlations from the H-3 ′′′ ’ with 3 ′ ′ ′ ′ -cin-9. Thus, graminifoloside B was defined as 1-(ss- D-glucopyranosyloxybenzyl-3,4-di- trans -cinnamoyl-6- acetyl)-2-(ss- D-glucopyranosyl-2-acetyl)-4-(ss- D-glucopyranosyloxybenzyl)-2 R -isobutylmalic acid.

sec.title: 2.1. Antioxidant activity
2.2. Cytocompatibility activity
sec.p: The isolated compounds were also investigated for their cytotoxicity against macrophage (RAW 264.7) cells at a range of 3.9–500 μg/mL. The results of cytotoxicity indicated that the compounds demonstrated a dose dependent toxicity against RAW 264.7 cell. Moreover, the isolated constituents at tested concentration of ~125 μg/mL showed > 70% of cell viability. The results suggested that phyto-constituents are more biocompatible.

sec.title: 2.3. Cytoprotective effects
sec.p: Oxidative stress caused by the excessive production of reactive oxygen species, results in cellular damage that leads to several diseases including aging, diabetes, and cardiovascular diseases. Cellular viability was investigated after exposure to varying concentration of H 2 O 2 (1–8 mM). The results revealed a concentration dependent cell viability ( Fig. 5 ). Hydrogen peroxide has been reported to mediate cell necrosis and death in both bacterial and cell-lines through the induction of intracellular free radical generation. Exposure of RAW 264.7 cells to 3 mM of H 2 O 2 resulted in a ~60% reduction of cell viability. However, pretreatment of RAW 264.7 cells with the isolated compounds (compounds 3, 5, 6 and 8) at concentrations of 7.81–125 mg /mL resulted in cytoprotective effect against H 2 O 2 induced cell mortality. The compounds treated cells demonstrated 39–77% increase in cell viability in presence of 3.0 mM of H 2 O 2 ( Fig. 6 ). This results collaborate with antioxidant efficacy of the compounds with effective attenuations of H 2 O 2 induced oxidative stress medicated cell death.
3. Conclusions
4. Experimental
4.1. General methods
All information regarding the general experimental procedures including the instruments and procedures were included in the supplementary information.
4.2. Plant material

The dried roots and rhizomes of
Arundina graminifolia D.Don Hochr (Orchidaceae)
were collected in
September 2010
at Joe Orchid Farm ( Chiang Mai , Thailand , GPS 18.919048339241826, 98.93458399321969) and the voucher samples (n ◦ 05–563) of the plant were authenticated and deposited at the herbarium of the Faculty of Science , Chiang Mai University , Thailand. The importation of the plant materials to France followed the guidelines of the
Convention on International Trade
in Endangered Species
.

4.4. Determination of the absolute configuration of the sugar moiety

was used for the determination of the absolute configuration of the sugar moiety. Briefly, 1 mg of the compound was solubilized 0.5 mL of 2 M HCl and subjected to reflux for 3 h. Thereafter, the solution was allowed to cool down and partitioned with n-butanol. The aqueous phase obtained after partitioning was concentrated under reduced pressure and derivatized with pyridine and 1-(trimethylsilyl) imidazole (4:1 v/v) for 60 min a temperature of 60 ◦ C. The derivatized sample was identified using a GC-MS Trace GC Ultra instrument with the following conditions: column; TR-5MS SQC (0.25 μm, 15 m × 0.25 mm ); Detection was achieved on a DSQII Thermo Scientific mass spectrometer (mass range of m/z 0 to 500). D-glucose was identified by comparing the retention time of the derivatized sample with the standard glucose.
4.5. Antioxidant activity
4.6. Biocompatibility studies on macrophage RAW264.7 cells

The biocompatibility of the isolated compounds were assessed on macrophage RAW 264.7 cells. Briefly, cells procured from the Institute of Research and Innovation, Walailak University, Nakhon Si Thammarat , were cultured in high glucose RPMI-1640 supplemented with 10% of fetal bovine serum and 100 μg/mL of streptomycin and 100 U/ml penicillin solution. Approximately 4 × 105 cells were seeded in 96-well plate and incubated at 37 ◦ C with 5% CO2. After 24 h of incubation, the culture medium was replaced with fresh RPMI-1640 as negative control in triplicate, whereas DMSO was tested for solvent effect. Moreover, cells were treated with 200 μL of varying concentrations of the isolated compounds (3.9–500 μg/mL) and incubated for 24 h. The viability of cells after treatment was analyzed using MTT assay and the optical density measured at 570 nm .

sec.title: 4.7. Cytoprotective effects against H2O2 medicated cytotoxicity
sec.p: The confluent monolayer of RAW 264.7 cells (4 × 105) were incubated with different concentrations of the isolated compounds ( 7.81–125 mg /mL) for 1 h. Further, the cells were treated with H2O2 (3.0 mM) and maintained at 37 ◦ C with 5% CO2 for 12 h. Cells were then washed and inhibitory effects of the compounds on H2O2 induced cytotoxicity was
evaluated by measuring cell mortality using MTT assay at 570 nm .

sec.title: Declaration of competing interest
sec.p: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
